concept_list: Euclidean Distance Geometry (EDG) For a given set of target interatomic distances, the solution to the 3D coordinates needs to minimize the deviation between the actual distances and the target distances: $L_g = \sum_{(u,v)\in E} \left| \| \hat{R}_u - \hat{R}_v \| - \hat{d}_{uv} \right|$

Periodic Boundary Conditions (PBCs) An atom $v$ is equivalent to the corresponding atom in the unit cell after being translated by the vector $k_1\mathbf{l}_1 + k_2\mathbf{l}_2 + k_3\mathbf{l}_3$, and distance calculations must take this translation into account: $\hat{R}_v \to \hat{R}_v + k_1 \mathbf{\hat{l}}_1 + k_2 \mathbf{\hat{l}}_2 + k_3 \mathbf{\hat{l}}_3$

Lattice Matrix and Coordinate Consistency Condition The lattice vectors $\mathbf{\hat{l}}_1, \mathbf{\hat{l}}_2, \mathbf{\hat{l}}_3$ must be consistent with the predicted lattice matrix $\hat{L}$, and periodic translations are implemented through this matrix.

Optimization with Bounded Constraints (Bounded Euclidean Distance, BED) If there is prediction uncertainty $\hat{b}_{ij}$ in the target distance, upper and lower bounds should be introduced: $\hat{d}^l_{ij} = \hat{d}_{ij} - e^{\hat{b}_{ij}}, \quad \hat{d}^u_{ij} = \hat{d}_{ij} + e^{\hat{b}_{ij}}$ Only the deviation of the actual distance beyond this range is penalized.

Theorem 1 [Gammage-Shende]: There is a homological mirror symmetry between T and Z_T fitting into the commutative diagram \[\xymatrix{ IndCoh(T) \ar[d]^{i^\ast} \ar[r]^\sim & Fuk(({\mathbb C}^\ast)^n,F)\ar[d]\\ IndCoh(\partial T) \ar[r]^\sim & Fuk(F) }\] Where Fuk(-,-) means the Fukaya-Seidel category of Z_T with respect to the general fiber F. $i$ is the natural inclusion. This diagram is such that the mirror of line bundles on T restricted to the boundary of T are Lagrangian spheres on F.
Theorem 2 [Orlov]: If IndCoh(X) is generated by a collection of vector bundles, and $Y\subset X$ is closed, then Perf(Y) is generated by restrictions of these vector bundles to Y.
Theorem 3 [Hanlon-Hicks-Lazarev]: Given a toric Deligne-Mumford stack X, there is a finite collection of line bundles that generate IndCoh(X).

Let $q$ be a prime power, $\mathbb{F}_q$ be the finite field with $q$ elements, $g$ be a primitive element (i.e., a multiplicative generator) of $\mathbb{F}_q$, and $\chi$ be the standard additive character on $\mathbb{F}_q$. Define the exponential sum $S_{\alpha}(a):=\sum_{x\in \mathbb{F}_q}\chi(ax^{p^\alpha+1}).$

Let $r$ and $\alpha$ be positive integers such that $r/\gcd(r,\alpha)$ is an odd number, $p$ be an odd prime, and $q=p^r$. Then we have $S_{\alpha}(a)=\begin{cases} (-1)^{r-1}\sqrt{q}\eta(a),& \mbox{if}p\equiv 1\mod 4,\\ (-1)^{r-1}\sqrt{-1}^r\sqrt{q}\eta(a),& \mbox{if}p\equiv 3\mod 4. \end{cases}$ where $\eta$ is the quadratic multiplicative character on $\BF_q$.

Let $r$ and $\alpha$ be positive integers, and $q=2^r$. Suppose $d:=\gcd(r,\alpha)$ such that $r/\gcd(r,\alpha)$ is an odd number. Then we have $S_{\alpha}(a)=\begin{cases} q,& \mbox{if}\ a=0,\\ 0,& \mbox{otherwise}. \end{cases}$

Suppose that $f(x)=a^{p^\alpha}x^{p^{2\alpha}}+ax$ is not a permutation polynomial over $\mathbb{F}_{p^r}$, and suppose $c\in \BF_{p^r}^*$ such that $f(c)=0$. Then $\sum_{\beta\in \BF_{p^{2\gcd(r,\alpha)}}\chi(a(\beta c)^{p^\alpha+1})=p^{2\gcd(r,\alpha)}$.

Theorem 1(Hermite’s criterion): Let $q$ be a prime power, and let $f(x)$ be a polynomial over the finite field $\mathbb{F}_q$. $f(x)$ is a permutation polynomial over $\mathbb{F}_q$ if and only if the following two properties hold: (1) $f(x)$ has exactly one root in $\mathbb{F}_q$; (2) For any positive integer $1\le i\le q-2$ satisfying $p\nmid i$, the degree of $[f(x)]^j \modulo x^q - x$ is at most $q-2$.
Theorem 2: Let $q$ be a prime power. If $n\mid q-1$, then there are no permutation polynomials of degree $n$ over the finite field $\mathbb{F}_q$.
Theorem 3: Let $q$ be an odd prime power. $x^{\frac{q+1}{2}}+ax$ is a permutation polynomial over $\mathbb{F}_q$ if and only if $a^2-1$ is a non-zero square number in $\mathbb{F}_q$.

Theorem 4: Let $q$ be a prime power and $n$ be a positive integer. If there exists a permutation polynomial of degree $n$ that is not an exceptional polynomial over the finite field $\mathbb{F}_q$, then $q\le (\frac{(n-2)(n-3)+\sqrt{(n-2)^2(n-3)^2+8n-12}}{2})^2$.
Theorem 5: Let $q$ be a prime power and $n$ be a positive integer. There exists an exceptional polynomial of degree $n$ over the finite field $\mathbb{F}_q$ if and only if $\gcd(n,q-1)=1$.
Energy conservation: a basic condition that must be satisfied in any reference frame (bubble wall frame)
Lorentz transformation: converting physical quantities from one reference frame to the reference frame to be solved

The number of particles $\Delta N_{\rm in}$ passing through area $\Delta A$ in time $\Delta t$ in the bubble wall frame: $\frac{\Delta N_{\rm in}}{\Delta A} &=& \frac{g_d}{(2 \pi)^3} \, \int d^3\vec{p} \, \int^{r_0-\frac{p_z \, \Delta t}{|\vec{p}|}}_{r_o} dr \, \mathcal{T}(\vec{p}) \, \Theta(-p_z) \, f(\vec{p};\vec{x}) \\ &=& \frac{g_d}{(2\pi)^3}\int d^3\vec{p} \, \Theta(-p_z-m_d) \, \Theta(-p_z) \, (-\frac{p_z \, \Delta t}{|\vec{p}|}) \, f(\vec{p};\vec{x}).
The distribution function adopts the Boltzmann approximation $f(p) = \exp(-\gamma_w(E-\vec{v_w}\dot \vec{p})/T)$

The (t,t) component of the gravitational field equation can be written as a first-order differential equation \begin{align} H^{t}{}_{t} = -\frac{6\,(f(r)-1)\,f'(r)}{r^{3}}\,. \end{align}
The subducting Indian continental lithosphere is too buoyant to exert a driving force sufficient to explain the ongoing India–Asia convergence.
Other external forces, such as push by the Indian Ocean ridge and pull of slabs, have had to be invoked
The northward Indian slab pull should have represented a role in modulating the motion of the initial India–Asia collisional convergence, but not sustain the process.
The far-field ridge push forces appears insufficient to explain the present-day deformation associated with the India–Asia convergence.

Seismic evidence reveals the deep-rooted mantle currents may influence the widely distributed continental lithospheric deformation stretching from the Himalaya to the Baikal-Mongolia Plateau by the asthenosphere flowing underneath.
A plume naturally developed in the mantle beneath the southern Neo-Tethys Ocean, producing the northward-directed mantle flow.
The rapid northward motions of the Indian Plate during the early Cenozoic have long been attributed to a driving force originating from the Réunion plume head
Pre-adsorbed oxygen species promote C-H bond cleavage on metals with lower activity, while inhibiting C-H bond cleavage on metals with higher activity
Rh and Pt doping significantly enhance the methane activation activity on Ag(111) surfaces, and Mn and Cr doping significantly enhance the O2 activation activity on Ag(111) surfaces

Definition (Variational convexity) The lsc function \( f \) will be called variationally convex at \( \bar{x} \) for \( \bar{v} \in \partial f (\bar{x}) \) if for some open convex neighborhood \( X \times V \) of \( (\bar{x}, \bar{v}) \) there is a convex lsc function \( \hat{f} \leq f \) on \( X \) such that, for some \( \varepsilon > 0 \), \([X_\varepsilon \times V] \cap \text{gph } \partial f = [X \times V] \cap \text{gph } \partial \hat{f}\) and \( f(x) = \hat{f}(x) \) at the common elements \( (x, v) \). It will be called variationally strongly convex at \( \bar{x} \) for \( \bar{v} \) with modulus \( \sigma > 0 \) if this holds with \( \hat{f} \) strongly convex on \( X \) with that modulus.
Theorem：Suppose that \( \{f_i\}_{i\in I} \) is a set of concave function, then function \( f(x):=\inf_{i\in I} f_i(x) \) is also a concave function.
The surface atomic arrangement in the high-index NiCo₂O₄ (112) facet enables it to maintain structural stability even in high-temperature environments

According to literature reports, researchers have found that if Nd is added to a manganese-based catalyst (30% Mn - 3% RE/TiO₂) modified with titanium dioxide as a carrier and modified by rare earth metals, it can reduce the average valence state of Mn elements. The XANES linear combination analysis further confirmed that Nd doping significantly increased the proportion of low-valence Mn oxides (Mn₂O₃, Mn₃O₄, MnO) and decreased the content of MnO₂. This valence rearrangement and the high dispersion of Mn species on the TiO₂ support (XRD and SEM results) optimize the low-temperature reduction of the catalyst, thereby improving its low-temperature NH₃-SCR activity.
Other researchers have found that monodonate and bridgen nitrate are the key reactants in the traditional catalyst reaction, which react with NH3 to form NH4-NO3- intermediates.

Interfacial Overlayer Modulation Strategy | A strategy that precisely regulates the microenvironment of the electrode-electrolyte interface and the electronic structure of catalyst surfaces by introducing strongly adsorbed functional molecules or thin films stably present at HER-relevant potentials. This strongly adsorbed overlayer can directly alter the intrinsic activity of catalysts rather than merely acting as a physical barrier.
Hydrogen Binding | According to the Sabatier Principle, an ideal catalyst should exhibit moderate adsorption strength toward reaction intermediates (denoted as *H in this context).

d-band Center Theory | A fundamental theory describing the catalytic activity of transition metals. It posits that the energy center of metal d-orbitals (d-band center) governs the strength of bonding with adsorbates.
A Geometric Arrays for Polynomials (GAP) code is a type of polynomial evaluation code where the evaluation points are the m-wise intersection points of a given set of hyperplanes in general position.
The relative distance δ of a code is defined as the ratio of its minimum distance to its total block length.
For a GAP_{m,d,t} code constructed using t hyperplanes where t > m+d, its minimum distance is at least (t-d choose m).
The block length of a GAP_{m,d,t} code constructed from t hyperplanes is exactly (t choose m).
TENSOR ISOMORPHISM (TI) is the problem of determining if two 3-way arrays are equivalent under the action of the product of general linear groups on each of the three indices.

A TI-complete problem is an isomorphism problem that is polynomial-time reducible to TENSOR ISOMORPHISM, and TENSOR ISOMORPHISM is also polynomial-time reducible to it. Examples include CUBIC FORM EQUIVALENCE and ALGEBRA ISOMORPHISM.

ALTERNATING MATRIX SPACE ISOMETRY (AMSI) is the problem of deciding if two tuples of alternating matrices, \((A_1, ..., A_m)\) and \((B_1, ..., B_m)\), are isometric, which is equivalent to testing the isomorphism of p-groups of class 2 and exponent p.
Isomorphism of p-groups of class 2 and exponent p of order \(N\) can be tested in time \(N^{\tilde{O}((\log N)^{1/2})}\).

There exists a polynomial-time reduction from TENSOR ISOMORPHISM for \(n \times m \times l\) tensors to ALTERNATING MATRIX SPACE ISOMETRY, where the resulting matrices have a size that is a linear function of \(n, m,\) and \(l\).

Block-Respecting Turing Machines. A multitape Turing machine where the computation is partitioned into time blocks of length $b(n)$, and each tape is partitioned into tape blocks of length $b(n)$. Tape heads only cross between tape blocks at the end of a time block.

Computation Graph. A directed acyclic graph used to model the information flow of a computation. For a block-respecting machine, nodes can represent the contents of tape blocks at specific time blocks, and edges represent the dependencies required to compute the contents of a later block from earlier ones.

The Tree Evaluation Problem. A computational problem where one is given a tree. Each leaf is labeled with a value (a b-bit string), and each internal node is labeled with a function. The value of an internal node is determined by applying its function to the values of its children. The goal is to compute the value of the root node.

Space-Efficient Algorithm for Tree Evaluation (Cook & Mertz). The Tree Evaluation problem on a tree with a maximum height of $h$, a maximum fan-in of $d$, and where each node's value is a b-bit string, can be solved in $O(d \cdot b + h \log(d \cdot b))$ space.

The $l_2$ heavy hitter algorithm is a sampling-based method where each site $i$ sends its frequency value $v_{ij}$ for element $j$ to a coordinator with a probability proportional to its squared value, specifically $p_{ij} = min\{1, \frac{3v_{ij}^{2}}{\epsilon^{2}F_{2}(v^{(i)})}\}$, where $F_{2}(v^{(i)})$ is the local second frequency moment at site $i$.

A key feature of the proposed $l_2$ heavy hitter algorithm is its error guarantee. It estimates each frequency $v_j$ with an additive error of $\epsilon l_{2}^{\prime}(v)$, where $l_{2}^{\prime}(v) = (\sum_{i=1}^{k}||v^{(i)}||_{2}^{2})^{1/2}$. This is an improvement over standard methods that guarantee an error of $\epsilon l_{2}(v)$.

To generalize from $l_2$ to $l_p$ heavy hitters without incurring a dependency on the universe size $n$, a thresholding technique is applied. Each site $i$ sparsifies its local frequency vector by setting any value $v_{ij}$ to zero if it is below a certain threshold, specifically if $v_{ij} < \frac{\epsilon l_{p}^{\prime}(v)}{k}$.
The expected communication cost of the proposed $l_2$ heavy hitter algorithm (concept_1) is $O(\frac{k \log n}{\epsilon^{2}})$ bits.

For a non-negative vector $x$ where each non-zero element $x_i$ satisfies $x_i \ge \beta l_p(x)$, the $l_2$ norm and $l_p$ norm are related by the inequality $l_{2}^{2}(x) \le \frac{1}{\beta^{p-2}}l_{p}^{2}(x)$. This is crucial for analyzing the sparsified vectors.

Spillover Representation: A method to encode a data structure using a pair `(m, k)`, which consists of a main bit string `m` of length `M` and an integer "spill" `k` from a universe `[K]`. This allows for a fine-grained, fractional space measurement of `$M + \log K$` bits.

Handling Heterogeneous Spills: The spills `k_i` are heterogeneous; they are drawn from `S` different integer universes `[K^{(s)}]` depending on their type `s`. The storage solution must correctly handle values from these distinct and type-dependent domains.

Auxiliary-Data Retrieval: A storage technique where the retrieval of primary data is made highly efficient (constant time, no redundancy) by leveraging a separate, large block of auxiliary data that is encoded alongside it.

Initial Key Partitioning (Distractor): The dictionary construction begins by using a k-wise independent hash function to pseudo-randomly partition the `n` keys from a universe `U` into the `L` buckets. The choice of hash function affects key distribution but not the final concatenation method.

Representational Incompatibility: A challenge in joint storage is that the numeric spills `k_i` (integers in `[K^{(s)}]`) and the word-based data `m_i` (elements in `GF(2^w)`) exist in different algebraic structures, requiring a common framework for unified storage and retrieval.

Base Conversion with Low Redundancy: A sequence of elements can be converted from base `p` to base `q` with a redundancy of only `$O(\log q)$` words. In this context, converting data for a structure of size `~L` incurs `$O(\log L)$` words of redundancy *per conversion operation*.

Prime Number Gaps: For any sufficiently large integer `n`, there exists a prime number in the interval `$[n, n + n^{7/11}]$`. This guarantees that the universe `$K^{(s)}$` for a spill can be rounded up to a nearby prime `$P^{(s)}$` for field operations with negligible space cost.

Lemma 2.5: Let $N$ be a positive integer and $p$ be a prime number coprime to $N$, then $\cos\left(\frac{2\pi p}{N}\right) = \frac{-1}{\phi(N)} + \frac{1}{\phi(N)} \sum_{\substack{\chi \mod N \\ \chi \neq \chi_0, \chi(-1)=1}} \tau(\overline{\chi}) \chi(p)$, where $\phi(N)$ is Euler's totient function (the number of positive integers less than or equal to $N$ and coprime to $N$), $\chi_0$ is the principal Dirichlet character (satisfying $\chi_0(a)=1$ when $(a,N)=1$), and $\tau(\overline{\chi})$ is the Gauss sum of the character $\overline{\chi}$.

Formula (2.13): For a Dirichlet character $\chi$ modulo $N$, we have $\frac{1}{\tau(\chi)} = \frac{\chi(-1)}{N} \tau(\overline{\chi})$, where $\overline{\chi}$ is the complex conjugate character of $\chi$, and $\tau(\overline{\chi})$ is the Gauss sum of $\overline{\chi}$.

Result in [BHP]: For any positive real number $x$, there exists a constant $\theta < 1$ such that the smallest prime number $\lceil x \rceil^{\mathfrak{p}}$ not less than $x$ satisfies $\lceil x \rceil^{\mathfrak{p}} - x < x^{\theta}$ (cited from the reference of Lemma 2.8).
Equidistribution Property: Weyl Criterion
Poset-diary is an anti chain in a partial order set (Can be seen as tree) such that each level has certain way to extend to next level.
Given a countable partial order Q, we let T(Q) be the set of all poset-diaries S such that (S, ⪯) is isomorphic to Q.

Integrated Fractional Brownian Motion (iFBM): Obtained by integrating a Fractional Brownian Motion with Hurst parameter \(H\), with a mean function \(m(x) = 0\). Its kernel function is \(k_{1,H}(x,x') = \int_0^x \int_0^{x'} k_{0,H}(z,z')dzdz'\).

Quasi-Uniform Partition: A sequence of partitions \((P_N)\) satisfies the condition that there exists a constant \(C_{\text{qu}} \geq 1\) such that \sup_N \frac{\max_n \Delta x_{N,n}}{\min_n \Delta x_{N,n}} = C_{\text{qu}}. In this case, \Delta x_{N,n} = \Theta(N^{-1}).

Asymptotic Order Comparison Rule: For two terms of the form \Theta(N^a) and \Theta(N^b) (where \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers), when \(N \to \infty\): if \(a > b\), then \Theta(N^a) is the dominant term (decays more slowly); if \(a = b\), the two terms are of the same order.

Explicit Expression for the Kernel Function of Integrated Fractional Brownian Motion (iFBM): \[\begin{aligned} k_{1,H}(x,x') &= \int_{0}^{x} \int_{0}^{x'} \frac{1}{2}\left(|z|^{2H} + |z'|^{2H} - |z-z'|^{2H}\right)dzdz' \\ &= \frac{1}{2(2H+1)}\left(x'x^{2H+1} + x(x')^{2H+1}\right) - \frac{1}{4(2H+1)(H+1)}\left[x^{2H+2} + (x')^{2H+2} - |x-x'|^{2H+2}\right] \end{aligned}\]

Generalized Binomial Theorem: For a real number \alpha and a small quantity \delta, \[(a - \delta)^\alpha = a^\alpha - \alpha a^{\alpha-1}\delta + \frac{\alpha(\alpha-1)}{2}a^{\alpha-2}\delta^2 + O(\delta^3) \], which holds only when \delta <<a.
Concept 1: RLOO Advantage Estimator: $$ \hat{\mathcal{A}}(y_j) = r(y_j) - \frac{1}{N-1} \sum_{k \neq j} r(y_k). $$
Concept 2: Pass Rate: $$\mathcal{P}_{x}(\theta) = \mathbb{E}_{y \sim \pi_{\theta}(\cdot|x)}[r(y)].$$
Concept 3: Law of Total Expectation: $$\mathbb{E}[X \cdot \mathbb{I}_A] = P(A)\mathbb{E}[X|A].$$
Concept 4: Linearity of Expectation: $$\mathbb{E}[X+Y] = \mathbb{E}[X] + \mathbb{E}[Y].$$
Concept 5: Probability of Independent Events: $$P(A \cap B) = P(A)P(B).$$

Concept 6: Statistical Independence: If a random variable $X$ is statistically independent of an event $A$, its conditional expectation given the event equals its unconditional expectation ($\mathbb{E}[X|A,B] = \mathbb{E}[X|B]$).
Concept 7: The Log-Derivative Trick: $$\nabla_{\theta}\mathbb{E}_{x \sim p_{\theta}}[f(x)] = \mathbb{E}_{x \sim p_{\theta}}[f(x) \nabla_{\theta} \log p_{\theta}(x)].$$
Concept 8: Conditional Score Function: $$\mathbb{E}[\nabla_{\theta} \log \pi_{\theta}(y_1 | x) | r(y_1) = 0] = - \frac{\nabla_{\theta} \mathcal{P}_x(\theta)}{1 - \mathcal{P}_x(\theta)}$$.

Two-Point Function of Operators Far from Defects in Holographic Defect Conformal Field Theory | Refers to the correlation function of two local operators inserted at positions far from the defect in holographic conformal field theories (defect CFTs) containing conformal defects. Its form can be expressed as $G\left(P_{1}, P_{2}\right)=\int_{AdS_{d+1}} d X_{1} \int_{AdS_{d+1}} d X_{2} G_{B \partial}\left(P_{1}, X_{1}\right) G_{B \partial}\left(P_{2}, X_{2}\right) G\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right)$, where $G_{B \partial}$ is the bulk-to-boundary propagator, and $G\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right)$ is the bulk two-point function in the presence of holographic defects. It has the physical meaning of a form factor describing the scattering of particles and extended objects in AdS. The integral measure $dX$ in this formula can be divided into parallel and perpendicular components

Parallel and Perpendicular Components | The integral variables $X_1$ and $X_2$ can be divided into components parallel to the defect and components perpendicular to the defect. $G\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right)$ has translational invariance for components parallel to the defect, but no translational invariance for perpendicular components.

Large AdS Radius Limit (Flat-Space Limit) | The limit case when the radius $R$ of AdS space is much larger than the intrinsic length scale $\ell_s$ of bulk physics (i.e., $R/\ell_s \to \infty$). At this time, $G\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right)$ is approximated as a flat spacetime form factor in position space, and the parallel component of $X_1$ is the $AdS_{d+1}$ measure (Fourier transformation cannot be performed, and the final result must retain the integral over the parallel component of $X_1$), while the perpendicular component of $X_1$ and all components of $(X_1 - X_2)$ are flat spacetime measures.

Schwinger Parametrization | A method to rewrite the propagator into an exponential form, which is convenient for calculations such as integration. For the bulk-to-boundary propagator $G_{B \partial}^{\Delta}(X, P)$, its Schwinger parametrization form is $G_{B \partial}^{\Delta}(X, P)=\frac{(-i)^{\Delta} R^{\Delta}}{\Gamma(\Delta) R^{(d-1) / 2} \ell_{s}^{\Delta}} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{d \beta}{\beta} \beta^{\Delta} e^{-2 i \beta P^{\| } \cdot X^{\| } / \ell_{s}} e^{-2 i \beta P^{\perp} \cdot X^{\perp} / \ell_{s}}$, where $\beta$ is the Schwinger parameter. This form decomposes the propagator into exponential terms parallel and perpendicular to the defect direction, facilitating subsequent momentum space transformation and other operations.

Fourier Transformation and Momentum Conservation | If the measure is flat spacetime, position space and momentum space are connected by Fourier transformation. If the measure is $AdS_{d+1}$, Fourier transformation cannot be performed.

Cumulative Regret. In a GP bandit problem, the cumulative regret $R_T$ is the sum of the difference between the reward of the optimal action $x^*$ and the chosen action $x_t$ over T steps: $R_T=\sum_{t \in[T]} f\left(x^*\right)-f\left(x_t\right)$.

Noiseless GP Bandit Setting. A sequential decision-making problem where at each step $t$, a learner selects a point $x_t$ and observes the reward directly without noise, i.e., $y_t=f\left(x_t\right)$. The function $f$ is assumed to be an element of a known Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Space (RKHS).

Phased Elimination (PE) Algorithm. An algorithm for GP bandits that divides time into batches. In each batch, it performs Maximum Variance Reduction (MVR) to select points. After each batch, it eliminates candidate points whose upper confidence bound (UCB) is lower than the maximum lower confidence bound (LCB), shrinking the search space for the next batch. The number of batches is logarithmic with respect to the total time horizon T, i.e., $O(\log T)$.
Squared Exponential (SE) Kernel. A commonly used kernel in GP models defined as $k_{S E}(x, \tilde{x})=\exp \left(-\frac{\|x-\tilde{x}\|_2^2}{2 l^2}\right)$, where $l$ is the lengthscale parameter.

Deterministic Confidence Bound for Noiseless Setting. In a noiseless setting ( $\lambda=0$ ), the true function $f(x)$ is deterministically bounded by the posterior mean $\mu_{0 I_t}$ and the posterior standard deviation $\sigma_{0 I_t}$ scaled by the RKHS norm bound B. Specifically, $\left|f(x)-\mu_{0 I_t}\left(x ; X_t, f_t\right)\right| \leq B \sigma_{0 I_t}\left(x ; X_t\right)$ holds for all $x$ and $t$.

Upper Bound of Posterior Variance for SE Kernel. For the MVR algorithm in a low-noise or noiseless setting with an SE kernel, the maximum posterior standard deviation after T steps, $\max _{x \in \bar{X}} \sigma_{\bar{\lambda}_T^2 I_T}\left(x ; X_{T, T}\right)$, decreases exponentially with T. Specifically, it is bounded by $O\left(\sqrt{\exp \left(-T^{\frac{1}{d+1}} \ln -\alpha T\right)}\right)$ for any $\alpha>0$ and for all T greater than some constant $\bar{T}$.

Mean Squared Error: The expected value of the squared deviation between the estimator and the true parameter, i.e., $\mathbb{E}\{(\hat{\tau}_{\ell}-\tau)^2\} = [\text{Bias}(\hat{\tau}_{\ell})]^2 + \text{Var}(\hat{\tau}_{\ell})$.
Quadratic Variation ($V_{d,\ell}$): A statistic constructed based on the linear combination of observations, used to separate the effect of the nugget parameter.
Boundedness of Higher-Order Derivatives of $K_M$: When $\nu = \ell$, the $2\ell$-th order partial derivative of the covariance function can be bounded by $|\log (\|x-y\|)|$.

Selection of Parameters $c_{i, d, \ell}^{k_1, \dots, k_d}$ Can Avoid the Influence of Low-Order Terms in the Mean and Covariance Function on Parameter Estimation: 1. $\sum_{0 \leq k_1, \dots, k_d \leq \ell} c_{i, d, \ell}^{k_1, \dots, k_d} x_d\left(i_1 + k_1 \omega_n, \dots, i_d + k_d \omega_n\right)^{\ell} = \ell! \left(\frac{\omega_n}{n}\right)^{\ell}$ 2. For all integers $l_1, \dots, l_d$ satisfying $0 \leq l_1, \dots, l_{d-1} \leq \ell$, $0 \leq l_d \leq \ell-1$ and $0 \leq l_1 + \dots + l_d \leq \ell$, we have: \[\sum_{0 \leq k_1, \dots, k_d \leq \ell} c_{i, d, \ell}^{k_1, \dots, k_d} \prod_{j=1}^d x_j\left(i_1 + k_1 \omega_n, \dots, i_d + k_d \omega_n\right)^{l_j} = 0\]
Equivalent Definition of Analytic Set: A is an analytic set if and only if A is the continuous image of a Polish space.

Jankov, von Neumann Uniformization Theorem: Let $X, Y$ be standard Borel spaces and $P \subseteq X \times Y$ be an analytic set. Then there exists a Σ-measurable function $f: X \to Y$ such that for all $x \in \text{proj}_X(P)$, $(x, f(x)) \in P$ holds.
Every analytic subset of the real numbers is Lebesgue measurable.
Lusin's Theorem: In real analysis, a measurable function is continuous on some compact set of positive measure (used to obtain the continuous function $\psi$).
If $A$ is a proper Lebesgue measurable subgroup of the real numbers, then the Lebesgue measure of $A$ is 0.

Formula: $\mathrm{SWP} = \frac{\eta_s \cdot I_s}{\mathrm{SEC}}$. Definition: SWP (Specific Water Production) refers to the water production volume corresponding to specific solar energy input (per unit area), where $\eta_s$ is the system's solar energy collection efficiency (dimensionless), $I_s$ is the incident solar irradiance (kW$\cdot$m$^{-2}$), and SEC is the specific energy consumption for water production (kWh$\cdot$m$^{-3}$).

Definition: Multistage distillation uses the latent heat of condensation from each stage to drive evaporation in the next stage, improving energy utilization efficiency; this study adopts a 10-stage TD device, and the number of stages directly affects GOR and theoretical efficiency. Formula: $\mathrm{GOR} = \frac{a^2 \dot{q}_{\mathrm{back}} + 4 a b \dot{q}_{\mathrm{side}}}{a^2 \dot{q}_{\mathrm{in}}}$, where $a$ and $b$ are the geometric parameters of the system, $\dot{q}_{\mathrm{back}}$, $\dot{q}_{\mathrm{side}}$, and $\dot{q}_{\mathrm{in}}$ are the heat fluxes of the back wall, side wall, and input heat respectively; $L$ is the energy required to evaporate 1 L of saltwater, which can be regarded as latent heat.

Formula: $\eta_{\mathrm{TD,th}} = \frac{\mathrm{GOR} \cdot L}{I_{\mathrm{th}}}$. Definition: $\eta_{\mathrm{TD,th}}$ is the thermal energy-to-water efficiency of thermal distillation, $L$ is the latent heat (kWh$\cdot$m$^{-3}$), and $I_{\mathrm{th}}$ is the thermal energy input (kWh).

Formula: $\eta_{\mathrm{PV}} = \frac{\text{Electrical power output}}{I_s \cdot A}$, $\eta_{\mathrm{T}} = \frac{\text{Thermal power output}}{I_s \cdot A}$. Definition: $\eta_{\mathrm{PV}}$ is the photovoltaic conversion efficiency, the ratio of the electrical power of the PV unit to the incident solar energy; $\eta_{\mathrm{T}}$ is the photothermal conversion efficiency, the ratio of the thermal power supplied to the TD module to the incident solar energy.

Formula: $\mathrm{SEC}_{\mathrm{RO}} = \frac{\Delta G}{\eta_{\mathrm{RO}}}$, $\Delta G = R T \left[ (1 - r) \cdot \ln\left( \frac{1}{1 - r} \right) \right]$. Definition: $\mathrm{SEC}_{\mathrm{RO}}$ is the electrical energy consumption per unit water production, $\Delta G$ is the minimum separation work (dependent on temperature $T$ and recovery rate $r$), and $\eta_{\mathrm{RO}}$ is the energy efficiency ratio of the RO system.

Formula: $\mathrm{SEC}_{\mathrm{TD}} = \frac{L}{\mathrm{GOR}}$. Definition: $\mathrm{SEC}_{\mathrm{TD}}$ is the thermal energy consumption per unit water production (converted to kWh$\cdot$m$^{-3}$), $L$ is the latent heat, and GOR is taken as the actual value of multistage distillation.

Formula: $\mathrm{SEC}_{\mathrm{hybrid}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{RO}} \cdot \mathrm{SEC}_{\mathrm{RO}} + V_{\mathrm{TD}} \cdot \mathrm{SEC}_{\mathrm{TD}}}{V_{\mathrm{RO}} + V_{\mathrm{TD}}}$. Definition: The total SEC of the hybrid system is the weighted average of the energy consumption of the RO and TD parts according to the water production ratio.

TD system: $\mathrm{SWP}_{\mathrm{TD}} = \frac{\eta_{\mathrm{th}} \cdot I_s}{\mathrm{SEC}_{\mathrm{TD}}}$; PV-RO system: $\mathrm{SWP}_{\mathrm{PV-RO}} = \frac{\eta_{\mathrm{PV}} \cdot I_s}{\mathrm{SEC}_{\mathrm{RO}}}$. Definition: Calculate the SWP of the pure TD and pure PV-RO systems respectively as the benchmark for comparison with the hybrid system.
自旋轨道耦合|一个相对论效应，描述了电子的自旋角动量与其绕原子核的轨道角动量之间的相互作用。该效应的强度随原子序数的增加而急剧增强。对于像铀（U）这样的重原子，其内层和半芯层的自旋轨道耦合效应非常显著，能级分裂可达10 eV量级。
“下层推动”效应|该效应描述了重原子中充满电子的、能量较低的轨道与配体价层轨道之间的泡利互斥作用 (Pauli Repulsion)。根据泡利不相容原理，成键区的价层轨道必须与芯层轨道保持正交，这种正交化要求会“推高”价层轨道的能量。 PFB效应将U的强SO分裂传递到了价带上。
芯层-价层轨道混合|在重原子体系中，半芯层轨道和价层轨道之间的能量差可能较小，且径向分布有重叠，这使得它们可以发生有效的轨道混合。这种混合导致了泡利排斥（PFB效应）。
晶体场对称性|原子周围的配体（或原子）会产生一个静电场（晶体场），其对称性决定了原子轨道的简并情况和轨道之间的相互作用（混合）方式。δ-[UO₃]具有很高的八面体（Oₕ）对称性。 这种高对称性使得轨道的简并性不会被晶体场轻易破坏，从而保证了其巨大的SO分裂效应可以完整地、最大程度地通过PFB机制传递给价带，而不会被低对称性带来的晶体场分裂效应所“猝灭” (quench)。

Fractional Laplacian is defined as $(-\Delta)^{s}u(x) = C_{s} \text{ P.V. } \int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{u(x) - u(y)}{|x-y|^{1+2s}} dy$, where $C_{s}=\frac{4^{s}}{\sqrt{\pi}}\frac{\Gamma(\frac{1}{2}+s)}{|\Gamma(-s)|}$.

For a nonlinear equation, the linearized operator describes the linear response of the system to small perturbations near a specific solution $u$. It is obtained by Fréchet differentiation of the equation. For this problem, its form is $\mathcal{L}_{u}=(-\Delta)^{s}-e^{u}$.
The null space (or kernel) of an operator $\mathcal{L}_u$ refers to the set of all functions that are mapped to the zero function by the operator.

If an equation remains invariant under a family of continuous transformations (such as translation), then differentiating the solution family with respect to the transformation parameter yields functions that are the 'generators' of this symmetry. They describe the infinitesimal changes of the solution along the direction of the symmetric transformation, so they must lie in the null space of the linearized operator.

Compact Self-Adjoint Operator is a class of well-behaved operators in functional analysis. A 'compact operator' usually maps bounded sets to relatively compact sets (popularly speaking, it has a 'smoothing' effect), while 'self-adjoint' is a generalization of real symmetric matrices in infinite-dimensional spaces. Such operators have excellent spectral theory, with real eigenvalues that can be clearly analyzed.

Perron-Frobenius Type Result is a class of theorems in spectral theory concerning operators with 'positivity' (for example, their integral kernel functions are always positive). Its classic conclusion is: the maximum eigenvalue of such operators is a positive real number, simple (i.e., the corresponding eigenspace is one-dimensional), and the corresponding eigenfunction can be taken as a strictly positive function.
Courant's Nodal Domain Theorem: The nodal lines of k-th eigenfunction $u_k$ divide $\Omega$ in no more than k subdomains, and no nodal line is a closed curve.

Weinstock's Inequality: This is a classic result in spectral geometry, which states that for any simply connected planar domain, $\sigma_1 \leq 2\pi/|\partial \Omega|$, where $|\partial \Omega|$ is the perimeter of the domain. In particular, if the domain is not a disk, the inequality is strict, i.e., $\sigma_1 < 2\pi/|\partial \Omega|$.

Geometric Perimeter Property of an Ellipse: For an ellipse with semi-major axis $a$ and semi-minor axis $b$ (let $a > b$), its perimeter $|\partial \mathcal{E}|$ is strictly greater than the perimeter $2\pi b$ of its inscribed circle (with radius $b$).

The second Neumann eigenvalue $\mu_2$ can be obtained by minimizing the Rayleigh quotient, but this minimization process is restricted to the set of all non-zero functions satisfying the orthogonality condition.

Its strict variational characterization is as follows:  $\mu_2 = \min_{\substack{u \in H^1(\Omega) \\ u \not\equiv 0 \\ \int_{\Omega} u \, dV = 0}} \frac{\int_{\Omega}|\nabla u|^{2} dV}{\int_{\Omega}|u|^{2} dV}$
where $H^1(\Omega)$ is the standard Sobolev space.
This formula indicates that $\mu_2$ is the minimum value of the ratio of energy to mass among all functions with zero integral.

For a domain $\Omega$ with an appropriate boundary, and two sufficiently smooth functions $\varphi$ and $\psi$, Green's first identity is expressed as: $\int_{\Omega} (\psi \Delta \varphi + 
abla\psi \cdot 
abla\varphi) dV = \int_{\partial\Omega} \psi (
abla\varphi \cdot \mathbf{
u}) dS = \int_{\partial\Omega} \psi  rac{\partial\varphi}{\partial
u} dS$

small disturbance (Section 1-141 of the paper): To handle the non-square-integrability of $E_t(z)$, a small disturbance $t' \to 0$ is introduced, and $I_2$ is expressed as the limit $I = \lim_{t' \to 0} \langle u E_t, E_t E_{t + t'} \rangle_{reg}$, allowing the integral to be processed via regularization methods.

Plancherel formula (Section 1-138 of the paper, Lemma 3.2): The regularized Plancherel formula decomposes the inner product into the sum of a constant term, discrete spectrum terms (cusp forms), continuous spectrum terms (Eisenstein series), and regularized residual terms, i.e., $\langle F, G \rangle_{reg} = \langle F, \sqrt{3/\pi} \rangle_{reg} \langle \sqrt{3/\pi}, G \rangle_{reg} + \sum_j \langle F, u_j \rangle \langle u_j, G \rangle + \frac{1}{4\pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}} \langle F, E_y \rangle_{reg} \langle E_y, G \rangle_{reg} dy + \cdots$.

Rankin-Selberg method (Section 1-125 of the paper): Establishes the connection between the inner product of products of automorphic functions and L-functions, for example, $\langle u E_t, \phi_k \rangle = \frac{\rho_j(1) \rho_k(1) \Lambda(1/2 + it, \phi_k \times u_j)}{2 \xi(1 + 2it)}$, converting integrals into estimates of L-functions.

triple product formula of Eisenstein series (Section 1-136 of the paper, Lemma 3.1): Zagier's regularized integral formula for the triple product of Eisenstein series, i.e., $\int_{\mathbb{X}}^{reg} E(z, 1/2 + s_1) E(z, 1/2 + s_2) E(z, 1/2 + s_3) d\mu z$ can be expressed as a product form of $\xi$-functions, used to analyze the contribution of continuous spectrum terms.

Stirling formula (Section 1-88 of the paper, Lemma 2.2): For a fixed $\sigma \in \mathbb{R}$, $\Gamma(\sigma + it) = e^{-\pi|t|/2} (1 + |t|)^{\sigma - 1/2} \exp\left(it \log \frac{|t|}{e}\right) (2\pi)^{1/2} i^{\sigma - 1/2} \left\{1 + \mathcal{O}(1/|t|)\right\}$, used to estimate the asymptotic behavior of the Γ-function and control the exponential decay factors related to spectral parameters.

subconvexity bound (Section 1-104 of the paper, Lemma 2.6): For small $\delta > 0$, $L(1/2 + 2it, \phi_k) \ll \left[(1 + |2t + t_k|)(1 + |2t - t_k|)\right]^{1/4 - \delta}$, used to control the growth of L-functions on the critical line.

fourth moment bound (Section 1-90 of the paper, Lemma 2.3): For $K^{1/3} \leq G \leq K$, $\sum_{K \leq t_k \leq K + G} |L(1/2, \phi_k)|^4 \ll G K^{1 + \varepsilon}$, used to estimate the upper bound of the sum of fourth powers of L-functions over short intervals.

Definition and Local Detailed Balance of Slow-Driven CRNs: Core reactions satisfy $k+_α/k−_α = exp{−ΔG_α/RT}$; the reservoir is slowly coupled with $ε$ and follows the law of mass action and the energetic relationship of chemical potential doing work.

Conserved Quantities/Moiety and Parameterization: The equilibrium solution of a closed system is $n0=[neq e^{ζ·η}]$, where $ζ$ is the cokernel basis of $(S0)^T$, usually corresponding to element conservation.

Singular Perturbation and Multiple Time Scales: Direct $ε$ expansion leads to secular divergence at $O(ε)$, requiring the introduction of $τ=εt$ and the application of the solvability condition $ζ^T∂τ n0=…$.
Universal Slow Dynamical Equation: $M(η)∂τη = ζ^T J^C(η)$, where $M=ζ^T[[neq e^{ζ·η}]]ζ$ and $J^C=r(z^C − neq e^{ζ·η}/Ω)$.

Independence from Core Rate Details and Dimensionality Reduction: The slow equation does not contain core activation energies and rates, and the steady state is also independent of core chemical potentials; $N$ species → $L$ degrees of freedom of conserved quantities.
Entropy Production and Thermodynamic Consistency: $T·Ṡ = −G·S·(k+−k−) + W·(r^+−r^−)$, and the dominant term under slow driving is $W·(r^+−r^−)+O(ε^2)$.

Steady-State Condition and Emergent Loops: $MC = L_br + C_C$ (number of reservoirs = number of broken conserved quantities + number of emergent loops); the existence of emergent loops is a necessary condition for reaching NESS.
Stochastic Extension: The Doi–Peliti and Hamilton–Jacobi formalisms give the same solvability condition $ζ^T(∂τ λ − J^C)=0$ for the slow equation, ensuring consistency at the large deviation level.

Local Detailed Balance/Microscopic Reversibility: $k+_α/k−_α = exp{−ΔG_α/RT}$ is a necessary condition for the existence of thermal equilibrium in a physical CRN and is used to constrain rate parameterization.
Rank-Nullity Relationship (Topological Counting) for Open Systems: Derived from rank-nullity, $MC = L_br + C_C$ links reservoirs, broken conservation laws, and emergent loops.
The Fluctuation-Dissipation Theorem (relativistic Einstein relation) gives the relationship between the damping coefficient $\eta_D(p)$ and $\kappa$

Local thermal equilibrium and isotropic Markovian white noise with the noise correlation \[ \langle \xi_i(t)\,\xi_j(t') \rangle \;=\; \kappa\,\delta_{ij}\,\delta(t-t')\,, \] and the equilibrium distribution is in the Maxwell–Jüttner form $f_{\mathrm{eq}}\propto e^{-E/T}$ (natural units $k_B=1$).
Einstein–Smoluchowski relation for spatial diffusion (defined in the small momentum limit): $\displaystyle D_s \equiv \frac{T}{M\,\eta_D(0)}$.
Damping coefficient in the small momentum limit $E\to M$: $\displaystyle \eta_D(0)$

Maxwell field equation of NLED, giving the relationship between $F_{tr}$, electric charge $q_e$, and $L_{\mathcal F}$: $\nabla_\mu\!\left(\mathcal L_{\mathcal F} F^{\mu\nu}\right)=0$, where $\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal F} = \partial \mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{NLED}}(F)/ \partial F$
Standard Ansatz for dyonic spherically symmetric fields: $F=dA=F_{tr}(r)\,dt\wedge dr+q_m\sin\theta\,d\theta\wedge d\phi$.
The electromagnetic field scalar is defined as $F=1/4 F_{\mu \nu}F^{\mu \nu}$
$m=2\ell+1, \ell⩾2$ defines the Lee metric parameters corresponding to the modulus $m$, where $m$ is an odd integer and $m \geq 3$.

Defining $\bar{n}'=\left( \bar{e} \mid -\bar{e} \right) = 2\bar{n}$ describes the relationship between the code length of the balance problem $\left( \bar{e} \mid -\bar{e} \right)$ and the extended code length $\bar{n}$, which is determined by the matrix structure $H_{\pm} = \left( \begin{array}{c} \bar{H} \\ \hline -\bar{H} \end{array} \right) $.

$w \leq \bar{n}(\ell - 1)$ is the weight constraint condition for the balanced Lee syndrome decoding problem, ensuring that the original vector $e$ can be effectively converted into the binary form $f$, where $f \in \{-1,0,1\}^{n\ell}$.

To ensure weight compatibility during the reduction process, the upper weight bound of the solution vector is required to be $\bar{n}(\ell - 1)$, so the following must be satisfied: $n\ell \leq \bar{n}(\ell - 1)$. Otherwise, even if the original problem has a solution, the newly constructed $g$ may exceed the upper weight bound, leading to reduction failure.

ETH Lower Bound for 3-Coloring: Under the Exponential Time Hypothesis (ETH), 3-Coloring of size $n$ requires time $2^{\Omega(n)}$. The lower bound here is for the original input size $n$, not the intermediate reduction parameters.

Selection of $t$ in the Reduction. In the reduction from 3-Coloring to $\mathrm{ColSub}(H)$, select $t = \frac{n}{2\gamma(H)}$. This $t$ is a blowup parameter that affects the size of the constructed $\mathrm{ColSub}(H)$ instance but does not change the fact that the ETH lower bound is transmitted in terms of $n$.

Relationship between Instance Size and $t$. The size of the generated $\mathrm{ColSub}(H)$ instance satisfies $s \leq c \cdot 3^t$, where $c$ is a constant. The exponent $t$ here changes with $\gamma(H)$, thereby affecting the size of $s$.

Transmission Principle of Complexity Lower Bounds. Reductions only affect the time complexity by a polynomial factor, and the core exponential part of the lower bound $2^{\Omega(n)}$ is still transmitted according to the original problem size $n$, without moving $\gamma(H)$ to the denominator of the exponent.

Position of $\gamma(H)$ in the Formula. $\gamma(H)$ changes the blowup size through $t$, thereby affecting the instance size $s$, but it does not directly enter the denominator of the exponent. The correct form should retain $2^{\Omega(n)}$, while $\gamma(H)$ only appears in the polynomial factor.

Froude number $Fr = U^*/(N^* L^*)$ describes the inhibitory effect of stable stratification on flow: it characterizes the strength of the inhibitory effect of stable stratification on flow. $Fr \ll 1$ indicates strong stratification, inhibiting vertical motion; $Fr \sim 1$ indicates that stratification and inertial effects are equivalent; otherwise, it indicates weak stratification. Thin-layer structures form under strong stratification, where $H^*$ is proportional to $U^*$.

Buoyancy Reynolds number $Re_b = \alpha^2 Re$ serves as a parameter to determine the importance of viscous effects: where $\alpha = H^*/L^*$ is the anisotropic aspect ratio, and $Re$ is the large-scale Reynolds number. Physical significance: It represents the ratio of vertical inertial forces to viscous forces in turbulence, and is a key parameter for judging whether viscous effects are important. When $Re_b \gg 1$, viscous effects can be neglected; when $Re_b \lesssim 1$, viscosity begins to control the flow.

Buoyancy Péclet number $Pe_b = Pr \, Re_b$ serves as a parameter to determine the importance of diffusion effects: Physical significance: It represents the relative importance of convection and diffusion in buoyancy transport (heat or mass transport) in turbulence. When $Pe_b \ll 1$, buoyancy diffusion is important at all scales (diffusion-dominated); when $Pe_b \gtrsim 1$, diffusion effects are secondary (non-diffusion-dominated).

Energy balance relation for vertical velocity controlled by wave dissipation mechanism in strongly stratified non-diffusive turbulence Physical significance: In the non-diffusive strongly stratified regime ($Pe_b \gtrsim O(1)$) and when the buoyancy Reynolds number is sufficiently large, the formation of vertical velocity is not only subject to geometric constraints but also needs to consider the energy exchange between small-scale internal waves and turbulence. This wave dissipation mechanism changes the source and dissipation balance of vertical kinetic energy, making the vertical velocity scaling no longer simply determined by the product of $H^*$ and $N^*$, but requiring a solution combining the combined effects of energy input, wave dissipation, and turbulent kinetic energy transfer.

Energy balance constraint for vertical kinetic energy suppressed by stratification In strongly stratified non-diffusive turbulence, vertical kinetic energy is mainly derived from the energy transfer from horizontal motion to the vertical direction via tilted vortex structures. The efficiency of this transfer is related to the stratification strength, satisfying that the ratio of the square of vertical velocity to the square of horizontal velocity is $\sim Fr$. Physical significance: Under strong stratification, vertical velocity is much smaller than horizontal velocity, and the ratio is determined by the Froude number.

Sumcheck Protocol → Arithmetize #SAT and 'unfold' it into a PCP skeleton, sumcheck → PCP skeleton: Arithmetize the counting assertion of CNF: Let $F$ be a field, and let $P:\{0,1\}^m 	o F$ be the arithmetized polynomial of $\Phi$ (individual degree $\leq d$). It is necessary to verify $\sum_{a \in \{0,1\}^m} P(a) = \gamma$. Sumcheck (interactive) defines a chain of polynomials for $i=1..m$ as $g_i(X) = \sum_{a_{i+1},\dots,a_m \in \{0,1\}} P(c_1,\dots,c_{i-1},X,a_{i+1},\dots,a_m)$, and checks $g_1(0) + g_1(1) = \gamma$, $g_i(c_i) = g_{i+1}(0) + g_{i+1}(1)$, $g_m(c_m) = P(c_1,\dots,c_m)$. Write the 'answer table/coefficient table for all challenge prefixes' (evaluation tables of $g_i$ and $P$) into the proof string at one time to obtain the baseline PCP; its checkability comes from the above consistency equations, but the bare unfolding will leak information (subsequent masking and simulability are required).

Masking and Constraint Detection in ZK IOP, masking $\alpha P + R$ & constraint detection: Select a random $\alpha \in F$ and a polynomial $R$ satisfying the zero-sum condition ($\sum_{a \in \{0,1\}^m} R(a) = 0$), and run Sumcheck on $\alpha P + R$ instead: declare $\sum_{a \in \{0,1\}^m} (\alpha P + R)(a) = \alpha \gamma$, and take the evaluation tables/commitments of $(\alpha P + R)$ and its intermediate polynomials as queryable proof components (oracle tables).

Combinatorial Nullstellensatz | Ensures the construction of polynomial terms that are identically zero on $\{0,1\}^m$, used for masking without breaking verification, thereby supporting perfect zero-knowledge.: Use the Combinatorial Nullstellensatz to construct vanishing terms on the hypercube, such as $Z(X) = \sum_{i=1}^m X_i(1-X_i)T_i(X)$ or $Z_H(X) = \prod_{a \in H} (X - a)$, let $R$ take the form $R(X) = Q(X) - Q(X_{rev}) + \sum_{i=1}^m X_i(1-X_i)T_i(X)$, thereby ensuring $R(a) = 0$ for all $a \in \{0,1\}^m$ (the 'zero-sum/zero-value' holds identically within the hypercube), while maintaining a sufficiently 'pseudorandom' distribution at other points in the field; substitute this $R$ into the $\alpha P + R$ masking in concept_2 to ensure that the summation and consistency checks are not broken, and at the same time weaken the recoverable information about $P$.

Encode proof components as 'random low-degree extensions (random LDE) consistent with boundary functions': Given a boundary $f:\{0,1\}^m \to F$, uniformly sample $\tilde{f}$ in the polynomial family $RM[F, m, d]$ such that $\tilde{f}|_{\{0,1\}^m} = f$, and provide a local simulator that outputs answers distributed identically to the evaluations of the 'true random $\tilde{f}$' at these points for any adaptive query sequence $(q_1,\dots,q_t)$; the PCP side uniformly embeds $\alpha P + R$ and several auxiliary tables (such as $T_i$) into this encoding, so that the local view seen by the malicious verifier (adaptive) is reproduced by the simulator, and the honest verifier can pre-fix queries (non-adaptive).

Low Individual Degree Test (LIDT). As a verification subroutine, it detects low-degree polynomials with a small number of queries, which is naturally suitable for the query mode of non-adaptive honest verifiers: On the field $F$, perform random sampling and one-dimensionalization on candidate polynomials expressed as $F^m \to F$ (such as $\alpha P + R$, each $g_i$, $T_i$) along the coordinate axis direction (randomly fix all variables except one coordinate), check whether the degree of the obtained univariate polynomial is $\leq d$ and spot-check consistency at multiple points; LIDT provides a decision threshold for 'belonging to/being close to the Reed–Muller low-degree code' with a small number of queries (the typical query complexity is on the order of $O(md \cdot poly(1/\varepsilon) \cdot log(1/\delta))$), thereby implementing the verification side as a low-degree/compatibility check with fixed query positions.

Cheeger's Inequality | For a graph $G$, $\frac{\lambda_2}{2} \leq \phi(G) \leq \sqrt{2 \lambda_2}$ holds. This is a standard inequality in spectral graph theory, connecting the second smallest eigenvalue and the graph conductance.

Abelian Cayley graphs have polynomial growth, i.e., doubling constant $\gamma_G \leq 2^{O(d)}$ | The volume growth of Abelian Cayley graphs is bounded by the doubling constant $\gamma_G = \max_{t \geq 0} |B(2t)| / |B(t)|$, where $B(t)$ is the ball of radius $t$, cited from [LM08].

Eigenvalue multiplicity can be bounded by the volume growth bound: $mul_{\lambda_2} \leq \gamma^{O(\log \gamma)}$ | The multiplicity $mul_{\lambda_2}$ of the second smallest eigenvalue $\lambda_2$ satisfies $mul_{\lambda_2} \leq \gamma^{O(\log \gamma)}$, where $\gamma$ is the doubling constant, bounded by volume growth.
Stirling's approximation: $\sqrt{2 \pi t} (t/e)^t \leq t! \leq 2 \sqrt{2 \pi t} (t/e)^t$
For $A\in{0,1}^{m\times r}$, $$ \Pr[\mathrm{Tribes}(A)=1]=1-(1-2^{-m})^{r}. $$ With $r=\lceil 2^{m}\ln 2\rceil$, this equals $1/2+o(1)$.
Pick one column and fix all its $m$ bits to 1 $\Rightarrow$ minimal 1-certificate size of $\mathrm{Tribes}$ is $m$.
For $\operatorname{MAJ}_m$, flipping one coordinate from $0$ to $1$ changes the output iff the sum of the remaining $m{-}1$ coordinates equals $m/2$.
Majority vote reaches constant distinguishing advantage with $t=\Theta(1/\delta^2)$ for expectation gap $\delta>0$.
Minimal DNF width of $f$ equals $C_1(f)$.
For $F=g\circ(f,\ldots,f)$ on disjoint variable blocks: $C_1(F)\le C_1(g)\cdot C_1(f)$.
For $g(z)=\mathbf 1[\sum z_i\ge k]$, $C_1(g)=k$.
Concept_1：DCCs：Disseminated Cancer Cells，播散性癌细胞，是指从原发性肿瘤脱离，并 通过血液或淋巴系统播散到身体其他远端器官（如肺、骨、肝）的癌细胞。其最关键的特征 是休眠（Dormancy）状态，这些细胞在到达远端器官后，并不会立即增殖形成可检测的转移 瘤；相反，它们可以进入一种持续数年、甚至数十年的“休眠”状态，保持代谢活性但不进 行细胞分裂。
Concept_2：上皮-间质转化（EMT）与间质-上皮转化（MET）：EMT 是癌细胞获得迁移和侵 袭能力的关键过程，其特征是上皮标志物（如 E-cadherin，EpCAM）下调、间质标志物（如 Vimentin 波形蛋白）上调；而 MET 则相反，被认为与休眠细胞被“唤醒”和形成转移灶有 关。
Concept_3：IAV，甲型流感病毒（Influenza A virus）为常见流感病毒，甲型流感病毒极易发 生变异。本研究中特指所用的实验毒株 A/PR/8/34（H1N1），简称 PR8；PR8 是经典的鼠适 应性甲型流感病毒，广泛用于小鼠呼吸道感染模型。本研究通过鼻内滴注（50μl PBS 含 500EIU 病毒），模拟人类呼吸道自然感染途径。
Concept_4：BALF 是 Bronchoalveolar Lavage Fluid 的缩写，即支气管肺泡灌洗液。它通过支 气管肺泡灌洗术（BAL）采集，将无菌生理盐水经支气管镜注入肺泡，随后负压回收，所得 液体即为 BALF，可反映肺部真实微环境。
Concept_5：MMTV-Her2（FVB/C57BL/6 背景）：MMTV-Her2 模型是 MMTV-LTR 驱动鼠 Erbb2（Neu，HER2 同源基因）的高表达，形成 HER2+乳腺癌。FVB 背景肿瘤发生早、生长 快；C57BL/6 背景肿瘤潜伏期略长，但免疫微环境更完整，适合免疫治疗研究。
Concept_6：MMTV-PyMT：MMTV-LTR 驱动多瘤病毒中间 T 抗原表达，激活 c-Src/PI3K/Akt 等信号通路。
Concept_7：iBALT（inducible bronchus-associated lymphoid tissue），即诱导性支气管相关淋 巴组织，是一种由炎症或感染诱导的三级淋巴结构，并非胚胎期就存在，而是在出生后肺受 到抗原（如病毒、细菌、过敏原）刺激时才在支气管周围或血管周围快速形成。
Concept_8：CD274，即 PD-L1，编码 I 型跨膜糖蛋白，含 IgV 样和 IgC 样胞外域；与 PD-1 受体结合后，抑制 T 细胞增殖、细胞毒性以及细胞因子释放，是肿瘤免疫逃逸的关键检查 点。
Concept_9：B2m，编码 12kDa 的可溶性蛋白，β-折叠片结构。若无 B2M，则 MHC-I 无法 折叠并转运至细胞膜表面，导致 CD8+ T 细胞无法识别靶细胞；肿瘤下调 B2m 或缺失突变可 逃避免疫监视。
Concept_10：细胞因子风暴与 IL-6/JAK/STAT3 通路：病毒感染会引发强烈的炎症反应，释 放大量细胞因子，如 IL-6。IL-6 通过激活 JAK/STAT3 信号通路，在促进细胞增殖、存活和 免疫调节中发挥核心作用，该通路也与癌症相关。

Concept_11：IL-6-CD4⁺ T 细胞轴，指 IL-6 与其受体复合物通过 JAK-STAT3 信号通路，直 接调控初始 CD4⁺ T 细胞的命运决定、增殖、效应功能及记忆形成的一套完整分子-细胞网 络。该轴在感染、肿瘤、自身免疫中均发挥重要作用。 IL-6最初激活DCC从间充质状态转化为混合表型，随后CD4+ T细胞主要发挥作用，通过抑制CD8+ T细胞等维持DCC活性状态，从而实现肿瘤转移。
Concept_12：GSEA：一种生物信息学方法，用于判断一组先定义的基因集合（如某个信号 通路的所有基因）在差异表达基因列表中是否集中出现。GSEA 不提前设定差异阈值，可发 现表达量变化微小但方向一致的通路。
Concept_1: B16-OVA-Tumor: 在B16细胞系中外源过表达鸡的卵清蛋白，鸡的卵清蛋白具有高免疫原性，可以更好地被免疫细胞识别，是免疫学的重要研究工具
Concept_2: OT-I T cells: CD8+ T细胞系，过表达一个识别OVA的肽段，可以配合OVA过表达细胞系使用

Concept_3: ACC：乙酰辅酶A羧化酶（ACC）是关键酶，它催化胞质乙酰辅酶A不可逆地羧化形成丙二酰辅酶A。该反应是从头脂肪酸合成的第一步和限速步骤 。哺乳动物表达两种不同的ACC同工酶：ACC1（也称为ACC-α）和ACC2（也称为ACC-β），它们具有约80%的氨基酸序列同源性，但在细胞定位和特定功能上有所不同 。ACC1： 主要定位于细胞质，并在脂肪生成组织（如肝脏、脂肪组织和哺乳期乳腺）中高表达。它是负责为脂肪酸合成提供丙二酰辅酶A的主要酶 。ACC2： 定位于线粒体外膜，尤其在心脏和肌肉中含量丰富。虽然它也产生丙二酰辅酶A，但其主要作用是通过抑制肉碱棕榈酰转移酶1（CPT1）来调节脂肪酸氧化，CPT1是控制脂肪酰辅酶A进入线粒体进行β-氧化的酶 。两种同工酶都受到饮食、激素（例如，胰岛素上调ACC1，胰高血糖素下调）和细胞能量状态的高度调节，特别是通过AMP激活的蛋白激酶（AMPK），当细胞能量（ATP）低时，AMPK会磷酸化并使ACC1和ACC2失活 。ACC1（合成）和ACC2（氧化调节）独特的细胞定位和主要功能揭示了一种复杂的代谢控制机制。

Concept_4: OCR：OCR（Oxygen Consumption Rate）：OCR是指细胞对氧气的消耗速率。Seahorse能量代谢分析仪通过测量细胞周围培养基中的溶解氧含量的变化来确定OCR。在测量过程中，细胞被置于特定的耗氧试剂中，如噻唑类化合物（例如，琥珀酸、马拉酸和氰化钠）。这些试剂会与细胞内的线粒体呼吸链相互作用，导致氧气消耗速率的变化。Seahorse能量代谢分析仪通过测量耗氧试剂与细胞周围培养基中溶解氧含量的变化，计算细胞的OCR。
Concept_5: 先前的实验证明，在体外环境下，如果能提高T细胞脂肪酸氧化代谢的速率，对于维持T细胞抗肿瘤这种免疫作用是有促进作用的，但是体内是否有作用尚不清楚
Concept_6: ND-646是一种ACC1和ACC2的抑制剂，可以结合ACC的biotin carboxylation domain，使得ACC无法二聚化
Concept_7: Bodipy-C16是检测16C的棕榈酸酯染色剂
Concept_8: etomoxir是一个CPT-1的不可逆抑制剂，阻止了乙酰CoA的转运，从而抑制脂肪酸的代谢途径

Conjecture 1 [Evans-Lekili]: An isolated compound Du Val singularity has crepant resolution if the symplectic cohomology groups of its Milnor fiber have constant ranks at all negative degree. The conjecture is expected to be true by various calculations. Symplectic cohomology is a symplectic geometric invariant for exact symplectic manifolds with boundary, which can be defined on the Milnor fiber of a singularity.

Definition 2 [Berglund-Hubsch-Krawitz]: The Berglund-Hubsch mirror for a weighted homogeneous polynomial W is defined as follows. Suppose W^\check contains n+1 monomials in n+1 variables. Collect the exponents of monomials in W^\check and package them into an integral (n+1)\times (n+1) matrix. Suppose the determinant of the matrix is nonzero. Then you take the tranpose of the matrix, call it A, and write down the corresponding polynomial W, such that the exponent matrix of W is precisely this new matrix A. Define a group $Γ_W :=\{ (t_0,t_1,...,t_{n+1}) \in (\mathbb C^\ast)^{n+2}: \sum_{j=1}^{n+1}t_j^{A_{ij}} =t_0t_1 ···t_{n+1}, for i = 1,...,n+1\}$. This is a finite extension of $\mathbb C^\ast$. The Milnor fiber of W^\check=0 is mirror to the Landau-Ginzburg orbifold (W, Γ_W) in an appropriate sense.

Theorem 3 [Evans-Lekili]: Given a weighted homogeneous isolated singularity X by equation $W^\check=0$ which is an affine hypersurface in $\mathbb C^{n+1}$, denote its Milnor fiber by V. One can compute $(W, Γ_W)$ by definition 2. Assuming that $HH^2(mf(A_{n+2},Γ_W,w))=0$, one has \[SH^∗(V ) \simeq HH^∗(mf(A_{n+2},Γ_W,W))\] Here HH denotes Hochschild cohomology and SH denotes symplectic cohomology.
Theorem 4 [Dyckerhoff, see also Lekili-Ueda, and Evans-Lekili]: There is a formula for computing $HH^∗(mf(A_{n+2},Γ_W,W))$ see https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.07374, equation 5.2.

Definition 5 [Reid]: Compound Du Val singularity is a class of 3-fold singularities such that a generic hyperplane (passing through the singular locus) intersects it on an canonical (ADE) surface singularity.
Theorem 6 [Reid]: For three fold singularity, being isolated compound Du Val is equivalent to being terminal.

Solar-driven seawater distillation typically operates as a closed or semi-enclosed system, where evaporation, condensation, and vapor transport occur within a confined chamber. The energy efficiency \eta depends on multiple coupled processes, including solar energy absorption, interfacial phase change, vapor diffusion, and heat dissipation. Environmental factors such as solar irradiance (q_{\mathrm{in}}), ambient temperature (T_{\mathrm{amb}}), wind speed (V_{\mathrm{wind}}), and relative humidity (RH) affect these processes simultaneously, but their effects are often interdependent and non-linear due to constrained mass and heat transfer pathways.

Wind speed (V_{\mathrm{wind}}) influences convective heat and mass transfer around the device. Stronger winds may promote vapor removal from the evaporation surface, enhancing diffusion, but they can also increase undesired convective heat losses. Thus, the net influence of wind speed is highly context-dependent and determined by system insulation and geometry.

Relative humidity (RH) affects the vapor concentration gradient between the evaporation surface and ambient air, which is the driving force for vapor diffusion. Higher RH generally reduces this driving potential, thereby slowing evaporation. However, in closed or semi-enclosed distillation systems, the impact of RH can be significantly mitigated by factors such as chamber design, condensation strategy, and air exchange rates.

Ambient temperature (T_{\mathrm{amb}}) determines the thermal boundary conditions between the distillation system and its surroundings. A higher T_{\mathrm{amb}} reduces convective and radiative heat losses, improves thermal retention, and enhances condensation performance. However, its contribution to efficiency cannot be directly inferred without considering interactions with other environmental parameters.

Solar irradiance (q_{\mathrm{in}}) provides the primary energy input for driving interfacial evaporation. The effective utilization of q_{\mathrm{in}} depends on several factors, including material absorptivity, thermal insulation quality, and condensation efficiency. Therefore, its contribution to overall system efficiency is system-dependent and influenced by device configuration.

The VCG with copies mechanism (Mechanism 1) is an algorithm that creates $2^l$ copies of each item, where $l$ is chosen randomly from $\{0, ..., r\}$. It runs the VCG auction on the new instance, then uses a rounding scheme for the final allocation and scales payments.

A q-valid rounding scheme is a function that converts an allocation from an instance with item copies back to the original single-copy instance. It ensures an agent's expected value is a $\frac{q}{2^l}$ fraction of their value in the copied instance.

The no-superstar-item assumption is defined by a parameter `c >= 1`, which reflects the diversity of agent preferences. It states the probability that any single item is an agent's favorite is at most `c/m`. This parameter `c` influences the final approximation ratio.

Asymptotic Equivalence for Logarithms: For any non-negative variable `x`, the expression `log(max{1, x})` is asymptotically equivalent to `log(1+x)` and can be written as $O(\log(1+x))$ in Big-O notation.

Under the Huber contamination model \(\mathcal{P}=(1-\gamma)P^\star+\gamma Q\), the minimax risk for second-order structure estimation satisfies (under suitable regularity) \[\inf_{\widehat{\theta}}\ \sup_{\mathcal{P}}\ \mathbb{E}\big[\|\widehat{\theta}-\theta^\star\|_{\mathrm{F}}\big]\ \ge\ c\,\gamma .\]
If \(\operatorname{rank}(\rho)\le r\) and \(\operatorname{rank}(\sigma)\le r\), then for \(\Delta:=\rho-\sigma\) one has \[\operatorname{rank}(\Delta)\ \le\ 2r .\]
\[\|\Delta\|_{1}\ \le\ \sqrt{\operatorname{rank}(\Delta)}\,\|\Delta\|_{\mathrm{F}},\qquad \|\Delta\|_{\mathrm{F}}\ \ge\ \frac{\|\Delta\|_{1}}{\sqrt{\operatorname{rank}(\Delta)}} .\]

(Tightness construction, exhibiting the \(\sqrt{r}\) “norm lifting” scale) Take rank-\(r\) orthogonal projections \(P,Q\) with \(PQ=0\), and set \[\rho=\tfrac{1}{r}P,\qquad \sigma=\tfrac{1}{r}Q,\qquad \Delta=\rho-\sigma,\] then \[\|\Delta\|_{1}=2,\qquad \|\Delta\|_{\mathrm{F}}=\sqrt{\tfrac{2}{r}}.\]
For any POVM \(M\) and states \(\rho,\sigma\), \[d_{\mathrm{TV}}\!\big(M(\rho),M(\sigma)\big)\ \le\ \tfrac12\,\|\rho-\sigma\|_{1}.\]

(Asymptotic-notation convention) \(\tilde{\Theta}(\cdot)\) denotes “equality up to polylogarithmic factors,” while \(\tilde{O}(\cdot)\) and \(\tilde{\Omega}(\cdot)\) denote upper and lower bounds ignoring polylogarithmic factors, respectively.

(Notation for the target rate) Let \(\varepsilon^\star(r,\gamma)\) denote the minimax achievable error rate in trace distance; “trace distance” conventionally refers to \(\tfrac{1}{2}\|\rho-\sigma\|_{1}\). Conclusions should be written as \(\varepsilon^\star(r,\gamma)=\tilde{\Theta}(\cdot)\) (ignoring polylogarithmic factors and constants).

Geometric Annealing Step Size: The pre-processing algorithm works via a geometric annealing process that expands the radius of a truncation ball by a multiplicative factor of `(1 + n^{-1/2})` at each step, proceeding until the radius covers the effective diameter of the distribution.
Stability of Roundedness: A near-isotropic distribution, when truncated to a slightly larger ball as part of the annealing process, is guaranteed to remain well-rounded.

Covariance Correction Procedure: To counteract the loss of perfect isotropy at each annealing step, a correction procedure is applied. This procedure repeatedly estimates the covariance from random samples and applies a linear transformation to amplify directions of low variance.
Sampler Cost Function: The efficiency of the sampling oracle used in the covariance correction procedure is determined by the operator norm of the covariance matrix, `||Cov π^X||`, not its trace.

Query Cost for Covariance Estimation: The total number of queries required by the covariance correction procedure to obtain a sufficiently accurate estimate is `Õ(n^2)` multiplied by the operator norm of the covariance matrix.
Bounding the Covariance Norm: The input to the covariance correction procedure is always a well-rounded distribution, for which the operator norm of its covariance is bounded by `O(n)`
General Complexity of Single-Copy Tomography. The worst-case sample complexity for tomography using arbitrary non-adaptive single-copy measurements is known to be $\Theta(8^N/\epsilon^2)$.

Pauli Operator Representation of a Quantum State. Any N-qubit quantum state $\rho$ can be expressed as a linear combination of Pauli observables: $\rho=\frac{1}{d}\sum_{P}Tr(\rho P)P$. The goal is to estimate the coefficients $Tr(\rho P)$.

Simultaneous Information Gain (Information Parallelism). A single Pauli basis measurement provides simultaneous statistical samples for all $2^N$ Pauli operators that are compatible with that basis, which is the key to the method's efficiency.

Effective Sample Amplification. Due to information parallelism, a Pauli observable of weight $w$ is effectively measured by all $3^{N-w}$ basis measurement settings that match its non-identity components.

Hilbert-Schmidt Error from Pauli Coefficients. The expected squared Hilbert-Schmidt error, $\mathbb{E}[||\hat{\rho}-\rho||_{HS}^2]$, is derived from the sum of the variances of the estimators for the individual Pauli coefficients. The calculation must properly account for the normalization of the Pauli basis relative to the Hilbert-Schmidt inner product.

MacDiarmid's Inequality. A concentration inequality used to convert a bound on the expected error of the state estimator into a high-probability bound, which introduces the required $log(1/\delta)$ factor.

Uniform Facility Location (UFL) is a clustering problem where the goal is to select a set of facilities $F \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ to minimize the total cost, defined as the sum of a fixed opening cost for each facility and the sum of distances from each data point in $X$ to its nearest facility in $F$. The objective function is $cost(X, F) := f|F| + \sum_{x \in X} dist(x, F)$.

The Doubling Dimension (ddim) of a metric space is the minimum value $t$ such that any ball in the space can be fully covered by at most $2^t$ balls of half the radius. It serves as a measure of the intrinsic dimensionality of the data.

A Random Linear Map is a function $\pi: \mathbb{R}^d \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^m$ used for dimension reduction, typically defined as $\pi: x \mapsto \frac{1}{\sqrt{m}}Gx$, where $G$ is a random matrix with i.i.d. entries from a standard Gaussian distribution $N(0,1)$.
The relation defining a free vortex, \( v \times r = c \), where \( v \) is velocity, \( r \) is radius, and \( c \) is a constant.

The relation between density and radius at the exit of a vortex nozzle, \( \frac{\rho}{\rho_{0}} = \left[1 - \frac{\gamma - 1}{2} \frac{1}{\left(r / r_{0}\right)^{2}}\right]^{\frac{1}{\gamma - 1}} \),  where:  - \( \gamma \) is the specific heat ratio of the gas;  - \( r_0 \) is the reference length

Determining the reference radius for a free vortex nozzle,  \[ r = r_0 \frac{\sqrt{X}}{M} \] where  \[ X = 1 + \frac{(\gamma - 1) M^{2}}{2} \] and the Mach number \( M \) corresponds to the local Mach number at a specific radius of the vortex nozzle exit.

Coarse Correlated Equilibrium (CCE): A game-theoretic solution concept where a correlated distribution over action profiles is stable if no player can improve their expected payoff by unilaterally deviating to a single, fixed alternative action.

T-sparse CCE: A CCE is defined as T-sparse if its underlying correlated distribution can be expressed as a convex combination of at most T product distributions (i.e., $\mu = \sum_{t=1}^{T} \alpha^{(t)}(x^{(t)} \otimes y^{(t)})$).

No-Regret Learning and Sparsity Connection: The empirical frequency of play over T iterations of a no-regret learning dynamic naturally forms a T-sparse distribution. Thus, a computational lower bound on the sparsity T needed to find an equilibrium provides a lower bound on the number of iterations required by any computationally bounded no-regret algorithm.

Polynomial Mixture Representation of CCE: Every game possesses a correlated equilibrium that can be represented as a convex combination of a polynomially-bounded number of product distributions. This representation is constructively derivable from the 'Ellipsoid Against Hope' proof technique.

Efficient Computation of Optimal CCE via Separation Oracle: For a succinctly represented game with a polynomial-sized 'reduced form,' a correlated equilibrium that maximizes a weighted sum of player utilities (social welfare) can be computed in polynomial time, provided that the corresponding 'separation problem' for the reduced form is solvable in polynomial time.
A one-pass streaming algorithm processes inputs sequentially, and its space complexity is lower-bounded by the mutual information between its memory and the input stream, i.e., space $\ge I(M; X)$.
Solving one embedded EDISJ instance via the $F_2$ reduction requires the algorithm to retain $\Omega(1/\epsilon^{2})$ bits of information about the corresponding part of the stream.
The paper's direct sum argument for dependent instances demonstrates that the information costs of the $\Theta(log(n))$ embedded instances are additive.
The total space complexity lower bound is the product of the number of embedded instances and the information cost per instance.

Potential Function: A function, $\Phi_{i} = \mathbb{E}_{x \sim \mathbb{F}_{2}^{u}}[b^{S_{i}(x)}]$, is defined to measure the imbalance of the ball distribution after $i$ steps of the hashing process, where $S_i(x)$ is the number of balls in the bin associated with $x$ and $b > 1$ is a chosen base.

Hashing via Incremental Kernel Construction: A random linear map is constructed by sequentially picking $k=u-l$ linearly independent kernel vectors. At each step $i$, the universe is partitioned into cosets of the subspace spanned by the first $i$ vectors, effectively merging bins.

Optimal Max-Load Benchmark: For a fully random function, the expected maximum load when hashing $n$ balls into $n$ bins is known to be $\Theta(\frac{\log n}{\log \log n})$, which is denoted as $OPT(n,n)$.

Expectation from Tail Probability: The expected value of a non-negative random variable $X$ can be calculated from its tail probability using the formula $\mathbb{E}[X] = \int_{0}^{\infty} Pr[X \ge t] dt$.

Potential to Max-Load Relationship: If any bin has a load of at least $m$, the final potential function $\Phi_k$ is bounded below by $\Phi_{k} > \frac{b^{m}}{2^{u-k}}$. This connects the abstract potential value to the concrete maximum load.
Conditional Expectation Bound: The potential functions satisfy the property $\mathbb{E}[\Phi_{i+1}|\Phi_{\le i}]\le \Phi_{i}^{2}$, which bounds the expected growth of the potential at each step.
Monotonicity Property: The potential functions also satisfy a stronger monotonicity property, $\Phi_{i+1}-1\ge2(\Phi_{i}-1)$, which is crucial for deriving a tight tail bound.

Quadratically Decaying Tail Bound: For a sequence of random variables $X_i$ satisfying the conditional expectation and monotonicity properties, the probability that the final term $X_k$ is large has a quadratically decaying tail bound: $Pr[X_{k}\ge t^{2^{k-1}}]\le48(\frac{X_{0}-1}{t-1})^{2}$.
Online Multicalibration is a setting where a learner must make calibrated predictions not just overall, but also conditionally on various contextually defined groups.

Expected Calibration Error (ECE) is a metric used to measure the calibration of a predictor, defined for a group $G$ as $ECE(G)=\sum_{p\in[0,1]}|\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathbb{I}[x_{t}\in G]\mathbb{I}[p_{t}=p](y_{t}-p)|$.
The Unbiased Prediction framework is an algorithm designed to produce predictions with low bias conditional on any finite collection of events.
Discretization is the process of dividing a continuous space, such as the prediction interval $[0,1]$, into a finite number of discrete buckets or points.

Group-calibration events, denoted as $E_{G,i}$, are defined for each group $G$ from a collection $\mathcal{G}$ and each discretized prediction bucket $P_i$. These events serve to connect the multicalibration problem to the unbiased prediction framework and are considered active if the context $x_t$ is in group $G$ and the prediction $p_t$ falls into bucket $i$.

Theorem 1 (Criteria for Permutation Polynomials): Let $p$ be a prime number, $r\ge 2$ be an integer, and $f(T)$ be an integer-coefficient polynomial. Then $f(T) \mod p^r$ is a permutation polynomial on the residue class ring $\mathbb{Z}/p^r\mathbb{Z}$ if and only if the following two conditions hold: (1) The polynomial $f(T) \mod p$ is a permutation over $\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}$; (2) For all $a \in \mathbb{Z}$, $f'(a) \not\equiv 0 \mod p$.

Theorem 2: Let $f(x)$ be an integer-coefficient polynomial and $r\ge 2$ be an integer. Let $\alpha$ be a solution to $f(x) \equiv 0 \mod p^{r-1}$. Then the number of solutions to $f(x) \equiv 0 \mod p^r$ that are congruent to $\alpha \mod p^{r-1}$ is: (1) $0$, if $f'(\alpha) \equiv 0 \mod p$ and $\alpha$ is not a solution to $f(x) \equiv 0 \mod p^r$; (2) $1$, if $f'(\alpha) \not\equiv 0 \mod p$; (3) $p$, if $f'(\alpha) \equiv 0 \mod p$ and $\alpha$ is a solution to $f(x) \equiv 0 \mod p^r$.

E-\delta-ISS (Exponential delta-Input-to-State Stability) definition: For two closed-loop trajectories of the same system, this property provides an exponentially weighted convolution-type upper bound on their state difference in terms of the initial difference and the disturbance sequence. It is used to transform "input/policy deviations" into "state deviations."

(i) Dynamics w.r.t. input: \|g(k,x,u) - g(k,x,v)\| \le L_u \|u - v\|. (ii) Stage/terminal cost: \|c_k(x,u) - c_k(y,z)\| \le M_x \|x-y\| + M_u \|u-z\| , \|F_k(x) - F_k(y)\| \le M_x \|x-y\|. (iii) Nominal policy w.r.t. state: \|\mu_k^\star(x) - \mu_k^\star(y)\| \le L \|x-y\|. This property linearly transfers "state/input deviations" into cost deviations.
\|\mu_{k+1}^\star(x) - \mu_k^\star(x)\| \le a_k . This captures the time-variability of the nominal policy and yields the term a^{\top}\tilde{\eta} in the final bound.

\|u_k^{\mu} - \mu_k^\star(x_k)\| \le \eta_k \, \|u_{k-1}^{\mu} - \mu_k^\star(x_k)\| ,\; \eta_k \in [0,1) . This compresses the cumulative input error into \tilde{\eta}_0 \|\delta u_0\| + (a + L \Delta)^{\top} \tilde{\eta}.

One needs to separate the coefficients into three groups, one with weight larger than one, another with weight smaller than one, and the other with weight equal to one. Those larger than one is called 'Coulomb branch parameters'. The number of them is the rank of the SCFT.
Those parameters with weight equal to one is called 'mass parameters'. The number of mass parameters is the rank of continuous flavor symmetry.
By comparing the CB spectrum with known results, we find that the SW curve describes the (A_1,A_{2g}) Argyres-Douglas theory.

To compute the central charges (a,c), we have the following formula: a=R(A)/4+R(B)/6+5r/24, c=R(B)/3+r/6. Here r=g is the rank of the SCFT, R(A)=\sum_i ([c_i]-1) where the sum ranges over all 'Coulomb branch parameters' c_i, while R(B) is a quantity that depends on the theory. For (A_1,A_{2g}) theory, R(B) is 2g(2g+1)/(2(2g+3)).
The algebra $\Lambda$ is called geometrically irreducible if the connected components of $mod_\Lambda(d)$ (the variety of $d$-dimensional modules of $\Lambda$) is irreducible for all $d$.

Let $kQ$ be a quiver path algebra, an ideal $I\subset kQ$ is called admissible if $M^h\subset I\subset M^2$ for some $h\geq 2$, where $M$ is the two-side ideal of $kQ$ generated by all arrows. The element $\rho\in I$ (relation) is linear combination of product of arrows like $'ac-bd'$ but not only product $'ac'$. The pair $(Q,I)$ is called quiver with relations.
For any finite dimensional $k$-algebra $\Lambda$, there exists a finite quiver $(Q,I)$ such that $\Lambda$ and $kQ/I$ are Morita equivalent. This quiver $Q$ is called the Gabriel quiver of $\Lambda$.

Let $Q'$ be two vertices $\{0,1\}$ with loops $\epsilon_0$ at $0$, $\epsilon_1$ at $1$ and two arrows $a,b: 1 \to 0$. Define $A' = kQ'/ \langle \epsilon_0^2, \epsilon_1^2, \epsilon_1a - a\epsilon_0\rangle$, then $A'$ is geometrically irreducible.
If $A=kQ/\left<R\right>$ for the quiver $Q$ in the instruction and some minimal set $R$ of relations, and $A$ is geometrically irreducible, then $deg \rho\in \{0,1\}$ for any $\rho\in R$.

L-Smoothness of the Target Function | For any noise \(\xi\), the function \(f(x, \xi)\) satisfies L-smoothness, i.e., \(\lVert \nabla f(x, \xi) - \nabla f(y, \xi) \rVert_2 \leq L \lVert x - y \rVert_2\), for all \(x, y\).

Bounded Variance of Stochastic Gradients | There exists a positive number \(\sigma\) such that for any noise \(\xi\), parameter \(x\), and \(
abla F(x) = \mathbb{E}[
abla f(x, \xi)]\), we have \(\mathbb{E} \left[ \lVert 
abla f(x, \xi) - 
abla F(x) Vert_2^2 ight] \leq \sigma^2\).

Stochastic Recursive Momentum (STORM) | STORM is a variant of standard momentum that achieves variance reduction by incorporating an additional term. In non-convex optimization, it attains a gradient complexity of \(O(\varepsilon^{-3})\), corresponding to a convergence rate of \(\min \mathbb{E}[\lVert \nabla F(x_t) \rVert^2] \leq O(T^{-2/3})\) to first-order stationary points after \(T\) iterations, without requiring snapshot points as in SVRG.

Convergence of Adaptive Gradient Methods like Adam | In non-convex optimization settings, adaptive gradient methods such as Adam achieve a convergence rate of \(O(T^{-1/2})\) to first-order stationary points.

Nonlinear Boussinesq-Fluid-Structure Interaction Model It describes an incompressible Boussinesq fluid surrounded by an elastic solid with heat transfer effect, where the continuity of velocity, temperature, and the normal vector of stress tensor holds at the coupling interface.

Galerkin Approximation Method It constructs finite-dimensional approximate solutions by expanding unknown functions with basis functions, converting partial differential equation problems into systems of ordinary differential equations for solution.

Compactness Theorem If a sequence is bounded in a function space and satisfies certain conditions, there exists a strongly convergent subsequence. This can be used to transition from approximate solutions to exact solutions.

Gronwall's Inequality If a function satisfies a specific differential inequality, an estimation formula for the function can be derived. It is used to prove the boundedness and stability of solutions.

Difference Quotient Method It estimates the derivatives of functions by defining difference quotients, which is used to prove the regularity of solutions and support the existence of smooth solutions.

For massless momenta q^{\mu}，we have the following parameterization：q^{\mu}=\omega\hat{q}^{\mu}=\omega(1+z\bar{z},z+\bar{z},-i(z-\bar{z}),1-z\bar{z})；For massive (or off-shell) momenta p^{\mu}，we have the parameterization: p^{\mu}=m\hat{p}^{\mu}=\frac{m}{2y}(1+y^2+w\bar{w},w+\bar{w},-i(w-\bar{w}),1-y^2-w\bar{w})

\mathcal{A}_{P\mu}(\Delta_{i},p_{n+1})=\int \prod_{i=1}^{n} d\omega_{i}\omega_{i}^{\Delta_{i}-1}A_{P\mu}\delta^{(4)}(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\omega_{i}\hat{q}_{i}-p_{n+1}) where \mathcal{A}_{P\mu} is the celestial BG current for gluons，A_{P\mu} is the gluon BG current in the 4-dimension flat spacetime，P is a set of length n, and the elements in P label the on-shell particles, say 1，2，...，n. In the momenta conservation delta function \delta^{(4)}(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\omega_{i}\hat{q}_{i}-p_{n+1})，\omega_{i}\hat{q}_{i} denotes the massless momentum and p denotes the momentum of the off-shell particle.
let P=i, then A_{i\mu}=\epsilon_{i\mu}.

Linear density of states (DOS) law in Dirac materials The DOS of graphene increases linearly near the Dirac point; the closer the energy is to the Dirac point, the lower the DOS, thereby suppressing the injection of high-energy hot electrons.

Bandgap suppresses the thermal tail effect Introducing a finite bandgap into the Dirac source prevents direct transitions from the valence band to the conduction band, further reducing the thermal tail distribution of high-energy carriers, thus lowering the subthreshold leakage current.
Ballistic transport assumption In the absence of electron-phonon scattering, the carrier energy distribution retains the characteristics of the injection end.
Landauer–Büttiker formula The Landauer–Büttiker formula establishes a connection between DOS and injection current: the injection current is regulated by DOS and the Fermi level difference.

Given a set of M sequence sets \(C=\) \(\{C^{0}, C^{1}, ..., C^{M-1}\}\) where each constituent set is composed of N multiphase sequences with each sequence having a length of L , i.e., \(C^{p}=\{c_{0}^{p}, c_{1}^{p}, ..., c_{N-1}^{p}\}\) for \(p=0,1, ..., M-1\) The set c is called an \((M, N, L, Z)\) -ZCCS, if \[\begin{aligned} \rho\left(C^{p}, C^{t} ; u\right) & \triangleq \sum_{\lambda=0}^{N-1} \rho\left(c_{\lambda}^{p}, c_{\lambda}^{t} ; u\right) \\ & = \begin{cases}N L, & u=0, p=t ; \\ 0, & 0<|u|<Z, p=t ; \\ 0, & |u|<Z, p \neq t .\end{cases} \end{aligned}\] where M , N , \(L,\) and Z represent the set size, flock size, sequence length, and the width of ZCZ width, respectively. If \(M=N\) and \(Z=L\) , the set is reduced to a complete complementary code, denoted by \((M, M, L)\) -CCC.

A matrix X of size \(\bar{L} \times \bar{M}\) can be represented by \( X \triangleq\left[s_{0}^{T}, s_{1}^{T}, ..., s_{\overline{M}-1}^{T}\right]\), where \(s_{v}=(s_{0, v}, s_{1, v}, ..., s_{\bar{L}-1, v})\) and \(\sum_{l=0}^{\bar{L}-1}|s_{l, v}|^{2}=E\) , for\(v=0,1, ..., \bar{M}-1\) .Let \(\delta_{max }=max _{v \neq t}|\sum_{l=0}^{\bar{L}-1} s_{l, v} s_{l, t}^{*}|\) be the maximum value of the inner product between any two distinct column vectors in X . Then we have \( \begin{aligned} \overline{M}(\overline{M}-1) \delta_{max }^{2}+\overline{M} & \geq \sum_{v=0}^{\overline{M}-1} \sum_{t=0}^{\overline{M}-1}\left|\sum_{l=0}^{\bar{L}-1} s_{l, v} s_{l, t}^{*}\right|^{2} \end{aligned}\)
Mass-action dynamics of open CRNs and precise formalization of concentration, flux, and mixed chemostats (CSTR as a special mixed case).
Indefinite growth ≡ divergence of at least one concentration and of mass density L_m; closed CRNs cannot grow; chemostatting choice controls growth conditions.
Second-law decomposition tailored for growth: TΣ̇ = ẇ_nc + ẇ_m − d_t G ≥ 0, with moiety vs. nonconservative work split.
